sen.j: 玉祖命（たまのおやのみこと）は、日本神話に登場する神である。
sen.e: Tamanooya no mikoto was a Shinto deity appearing in the Japanese Mythology.
Tamanooya no mikoto was a Shinto deity appearing in Japanese Mythology.
Tamanooya no Mikoto was a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: 表現を他ファイルと統一しました。

sen.j: 玉造部（たまつくりべ）の祖神とされる。
sen.e: He was an ancestral deity of Tamatsukuribe (the jewel-making clans).
He was an ancestral deity of Tamatsukuribe (the jewel-making clans).
He was an ancestral deity of Tamatsukuribe (the jewel-making clans).

sen.j: 古事記にのみ登場する。
sen.e: He appears only in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters).
He appears only in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters).
He appears only in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: 日本書紀にはこの名前の神は登場しないが、同神と見られる神が登場する。
sen.e: A deity of this name does not appear in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) while a deity who seems to be identical to this deity appears.
A deity of this name does not appear in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) while there appears an identical deity.
A deity of this name does not appear in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) while there appears an identical deity.
Descriptions in mythology
Descriptions in mythology
Descriptions in mythology

sen.j: 岩戸隠れの際に八尺瓊勾玉（ヤサカニノマガタマ）を作った。
sen.e: At the time of Iwatogakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess, in the heavenly rock cave), he created Yasakani no magatama (the jewel of Yasakani).
At the time of Iwatogakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess, in the heavenly rock cave), he created Yasakani no magatama (the jewel of Yasakani).
At the time of Iwatogakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess, in the heavenly rock cave), he created Yasakani no magatama (the jewel of Yasakani).

sen.j: 天孫降臨の際ニニギに附き従って天降るよう命じられ、天児屋命（あめのこやね）、フトダマ（ふとだま）、アメノウズメ（あめのうずめ）、イシコリドメ（いしこりどめ）と共に五伴緒の一人として随伴した。
sen.e: At the advent of the Sun-Goddess's grandson, he was ordered to descend onto the earth to accompany Ninigi (the grandson of the Sun Goddess) as one of Itsutomonoo (five deities later to become ancestral deities of the five clans) along with Amenokoyane, Futodama, Amenouzume, and Ishikoridome.
sen.cmt: 「五伴緒」の用語集の訳を一部変更してあります
sen.e: At the advent of the Sun-Goddess's grandson, he was ordered to descend onto the earth to accompany Ninigi (the grandson of the Sun Goddess) as one of Itsutomonoo (five deities later to become ancestral deities of the five clans) along with Amenokoyane, Futodama, Amenouzume, and Ishikoridome.

Upon Tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess), he was ordered to descend onto the earth to accompany Ninigi (the grandson of the Sun Goddess) as one of Itsutomonoo (five deities later to become ancestral deities of the five clans) along with Amenokoyane, Futodama, Amenouzume and Ishikoridome.
sen.cmt: 天孫降臨 を追加しました。

sen.j: 日本書紀の岩戸隠れの段では、八尺瓊勾玉を作ったのは「玉造部の遠祖・豊玉神（とよたまのかみ）」（第二の一書）、「玉作の遠祖、イザナギの児・天明玉命（あめのあかるたまのみこと）」（第三の一書）としている。
sen.e: In the story of Iwatogakure in Nihonshoki, the one who created Yasakani no magatama is "Toyotama no kami," the forefather of the jewel-making clans (Arufumi [supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki] Vol. 2) or "Amenoakarutama no mikoto," a child of Izanagi (the divine creator of Japan) and the forefather of the jewel-making clans (Arufumi Vol. 3).
sen.cmt: 「一書 （あるふみ）」の用語集の訳を一部変更してあります
sen.e: In the story of Iwatogakure in Nihonshoki, the one who created Yasakani no magatama is "Toyotama no kami," the forefather of the jewel-making clans (Arufumi [supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki] Vol. 2) or "Amenoakarutama no mikoto," a child of Izanagi (the divine creator of Japan) and the forefather of the jewel-making clans (Arufumi Vol. 3).

In the story of Iwatogakure in Nihonshoki, the one who created Yasakani no magatama is 'Toyotama no Kami,' the forefather of the jewel-making clans (Arufumi [supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki] Vol. 2) or 'Amenoakarutama no Mikoto,' a child of Izanagi (the divine creator of Japan) and the forefather of the jewel-making clans (Arufumi Vol. 3).
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。"→ ' としました。

sen.j: どちらも玉造部の祖としていることから玉祖命と同神と考えられる。
sen.e: As both are regarded as ancestral deities of the jewel-making clans, they are probably identical to Tamanooya no mikoto.
As both are regarded as ancestral deities of the jewel-making clans, they are probably identical to Tamanooya no mikoto.
As both are regarded as ancestral deities of the jewel-making clans, they are probably identical to Tamanooya no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.e: Comments
Comments
Explanation
sen.cmt: 他ファイルと統一しました。

sen.j: 名前は玉造部の祖神の意味であり、勾玉を作る者の意味でもある。
sen.e: The name of this deity means an ancestral deity of the jewel-making clans as well as a maker of Magatama (a comma-shaped bead).
The name of this deity means an ancestral deity of the jewel-making clans as well as a maker of Magatama (a comma-shaped bead).
The name of this deity means an ancestral deity of the jewel-making clans as well as a maker of Magatama (a comma-shaped bead).

sen.j: 玉（勾玉）の神であることから宝石・時計（水晶が使われる）業者に、レンズのことを「玉」とも言うことから眼鏡・カメラ業者に信仰されている。
sen.e: As he was the god of tama or magatama (jewels), he was worshiped by jewel and watch traders or makers (because crystal is used for them), and also by glasses and camera traders or makers because a lens is sometimes called "tama" (jewels) in Japanese.

As he was the god of tama or magatama (jewels), he was worshiped by jewel and watch traders or makers (because crystal is used for them), and also by glasses and camera traders or makers because a lens is sometimes called "tama" (jewels) in Japanese.

As he was the god of tama or magatama (jewels), he was worshiped by jewel and watch traders or makers (because crystal is used for them), and also by glasses and camera traders or makers because a lens is sometimes called 'tama' (jewels) in Japanese.

sen.j: 玉祖神社 (防府市)（山口県防府市）、石作玉作神社（滋賀県伊香郡）などに祀られている。
sen.e: He is enshrined in the Tamanooya-jinja Shrine (Hofu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture) and the Ishitsukuri tamatsukuri-jinja Shrine (Ika-gun, Shiga Prefecture).
He is enshrined in the Tamanooya-jinja Shrine (Hofu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture) and the Ishitsukuri tamatsukuri-jinja Shrine (Ika-gun, Shiga Prefecture).
He is enshrined in the Tamanooya-jinja Shrine (Hofu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture), Ishitsukuri tamatsukuri-jinja Shrine (Ika-gun, Shiga Prefecture), etc.
